On Fri, Jun 7, 2019 at 11:31 PM Cody Mejeur <cmejeur@gmail.com> wrote:
Hello All,
I’ve followed this thread pretty closely as a trans game studies scholar, and what I’ve read here isn’t really reassuring. Given how LGBTQ folks often face harassment even in supposedly safe and accepting places, reassurances that it will *probably* be fine, and the government will *probably* look the other way for foreigners presenting on queer experiences and studies, and queer participants will be *relatively* safe ring pretty hollow. I was particularly alarmed when I read that LGB is probably fine, but the Ts might have to worry. I don’t doubt that that is likely an accurate reflection of the situation given how trans, genderqueer, and nonbinary folks are most frequently targeted for harassment, assault, and legislation. However a situation where only some members of the LGBTQ community are welcome or safe isn’t inclusive or helpful.

The teleconferencing option, while better than nothing, feels like a bandage on the larger issue—presenting from a distance often involves just giving the presentation and being involved with one panel and then leaving, which means missing out on a lot of the discussion and networking that makes conferencing valuable in the first place. It might be the best option available for providing safe presentation options to queer and particularly trans game studies scholars if the conference is to continue in St. Petersburg, but it’s not an ideal or particularly inclusive solution. I don’t have an easy answer to this because there isn’t one, but it seems to me that the conference has to decide between safety and support for LGBTQ game scholars and the importance of holding the conference in different locations that allow more people to participate. Whatever is decided here and moving forward, I think it’s important that the safety of queer folks not be sacrificed in the name of holding a conference in more locations, and ideally finding conference locations that accomplish both. I do hope that the St. Petersburg conference will provide opportunities to present for folks who aren’t able to make other international conferences and particularly local LGBTQ folks, though it seems that they too might have to be careful about what they present at the conference.

I would also humbly submit that if you’re working on a trans or queer game as a cisgendered and/or straight scholar and think that the queerness of that game is coincidental or not the main point, that you may need to think carefully about your positionality in relationship to that game, how you are using it, and to what ends. The minimization of queerness in games is a longstanding heteronormative project, and it would be disappointing to see game studies scholarship continue to contribute to it.

Best Regards,
Cody Mejeur, PhD
Michigan State University

On Jun 7, 2019, at 3:45 PM, Alesja Serada <alesja.serada@GMAIL.COM> wrote:

The EU already tried it with Belarus. That project failed. A new class of conference guests emerged really quickly - those who are professionals at fundraising but don't actually contribute to any community. So, no funding for Belarusians now - if the system can be exploited, it will be exploited, and especially with funding.

On Fri, Jun 7, 2019 at 10:41 PM K.Becker (gmail) <becker.minkhollow@gmail.com> wrote:

I think if we REALLY want to make a statement, then we need to only hold conferences in places that do NOT have problematic discriminatory laws. Instead, we need to hold them as close as possible to those places, and then raise funds to help make it possible for students and other precarious faculty from those nearby countries to attend.

Holding a conference in a place that officially outlaws LGBTQ people also means that the papers submitted to the conference must be censored, because any kind of unbiased research related to LGBTQ issues is also likely to be dangerous. That's NOT what scholarship is supposed to be about.

Katrin Becker, PhD (sent from gmail)
President, Mink Hollow Media
Adjunct Professor, Mount Royal University (Calgary, AB, Canada)
Author: Choosing and Using Digital Games in the Classroom – A Practical Guide, Springer, 2016
and The Guide to Computer Simulations and Games, Wiley, 2011
Owner Mink Hollow Farm

On 6/7/2019 1:23 PM, Carl Therrien wrote:
Dear Michael,

I'm just trying to think of solutions that would make participants feel safe to submit. People on location know best if they could be held accountable for the presentations made by participants outside the country. It might seem a bit paranoid to think the government would go to the extent of intercepting and listening if it is not presented as LGBT related, but in such a context it would not be surprising that authorities pay close attention to any event in academia and be very proactive about holding people accountable. I trust orgnizers know best about this.

Again, no easy solutions. It is hard to balance the benefits for the local communities of having these conferences be hosted in parts of the world with violent regimes and the need to be as inclusive as possible for every instalment of the conference. 

Best,

Carl Therrien
Professeur agrégé
